Title: Lake effect snow is expected to continue pummeling parts of the Northeast and Midwest
Description: Some areas across the Great Lakes region have already received up to 3 feet of lake effect snow. (Image credit: John Normile)

Title: Syrian rebels gain major ground in Aleppo after years of a largely stagnant conflict
Description: Syrian rebels seized much of the country's second-largest city after a stunning couple of days in which they've reignited a conflict that's been largely static for years.

Title: Syrian rebels have taken parts of Aleppo. What does that mean for the war?
Description: NPR's Eric Deggans speaks with Dareen Khalifa of the International Crisis Group about Syrian rebels taking control of parts of Aleppo.

Title: A program in Michigan gives high schoolers a jump start in their careers
Description: A program in Allegan, Mich., teaches trades to high schoolers.

Title: UN says it is halting aid through main Gaza crossing because route is too dangerous
Description: The U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees said Sunday it is halting aid deliveries through the main cargo crossing into Gaza because of the threat of armed gangs who have looted recent convoys. (Image credit: Tsafrir Abayov/AP)

Title: The 'Chinese Exclusion Era' shows how Trump's mass deportation plan could unfold
Description: Donald Trump promises to deport millions of unauthorized immigrants once he returns to the White House. If he follows through, the scale of it would be unlike anything we've seen in our lifetimes.Many supporters of Trump's mass deportation agenda say expelling unauthorized immigrants will help the US economy. But a look back at America's first major immigration crackdown suggests otherwise.On this episode, host Adrian Ma and his colleagues from NPR's The Indicator podcast look at that immigration crackdown during the 'Chinese Exclusion Era,' and the economic impact it had on the West. For a deeper dive into the economic his...

Title: The 'magical' advent calendar that's as big as a town hall
Description: A small town in Germany turns its town hall into the 'world's largest' advent calendar each December. It started as a way to boost businesses in the winter, but it's grown to mean much more. (Image credit: Hubert Grimmig)

Title: Protesters gather for third night of demonstrations after Georgia announces suspension of EU talks
Description: Protesters gathered across Georgia on Saturday night in a third straight night of demonstrations against the government's decision to suspend negotiations to join the European Union. (Image credit: Zurab Tsertsvadze/AP)

Title: Heavy snow blankets parts of the U.S. during busy holiday travel weekend
Description: Frigid air was expected to move over the eastern third of the U.S. by Monday, while heavy snow was forecast to cause hazards in the Great Lakes, Plains and Midwest regions. (Image credit: Cara Anna)

Title: FIFA should pay workers harmed in building World Cup venues, its committee report says
Description: The report said the main responsibility lay with the workers' direct employers and the Qatari government, but noted that 'a credible argument can be made' that FIFA played a role as well. (Image credit: Francois Mori)

Title: How a Syrian rebel group pulled off its stunning seizure of Aleppo
Description: Over a few days, rebel fighters in northern Syria have launched incursions into several major cities with little resistance from government troops. (Image credit: Omar Albam)

Title: In Syria, rebels take control of the country's largest city, Aleppo
Description: NPR's Adrian Ma speaks with Lina Khatib of Chatam House, about the significance of rebel groups entering the city of Aleppo, Syria, in a conflict that many believed had reached a stalemate.

Title: Examining the significance of the Israel-Hezbollah ceasefire agreement
World Central Kitchen workers killed by Israeli airstrike, Gaza health ministry says
Description: An Israeli airstrike hit a car in the Gaza Strip on Saturday, killing five people, including at least three employees with the food aid charity. World Central Kitchen said that it was 'urgently seeking more details.' (Image credit: Bashar Taleb)

Title: Post-ceasefire with Israel, Lebanon reckons with large-scale damage and displacement
Description: Parts of southern Lebanon now look like Gaza. The World Bank estimates $8.5 billion in damage to Lebanon from the Israel-Hezbollah war.

Title: SunFed cucumbers and Costco eggs recalled for potential salmonella contamination
Description: Cucumbers shipped to the U.S. and Canada, and organic eggs sold in 25 Costco stores in five southern U.S. states, were recalled this week for potential salmonella contamination. (Image credit: Jacquelyn Martin)

Title: Reporter Journal: A sunrise trek through wild solitude in New York City
Description: New York City is home to more than eight million people but NPR's Brian Mann mapped out an urban hike through solitude and parkland wildness. (Image credit: Brian Mann)

Title: Ireland headed for coalition government, exit poll suggests
Description: An exit poll in Ireland's parliamentary election released late Friday suggests the three biggest parties have won roughly equal shares and the country is headed for another coalition government. (Image credit: Brian Lawless)

Title: In a shock offensive, insurgents breach Aleppo, Syria's largest city
Description: Insurgents breached Syria's largest city Friday and clashed with government forces for the first time since 2016, in a surprise attack that sent residents fleeing. (Image credit: Ghaith Alsayed)

Title: Canadian Prime Minister Trudeau flies to Florida to meet with Trump after tariffs threat
Description: Trudeau flew to Florida on Friday to have dinner with President-elect Donald Trump at his Mar-a-Lago club after Trump threatened to impose sweeping tariffs on Canadian products. (Image credit: Carolyn Kaster)

Title: Chinese crypto businessman eats his controversial $6.2 million banana art piece
Description: Justin Sun uploaded a video of himself eating the $6.2 million absurdist piece conceptualized by Italian artist Maurizio Cattelan. (Image credit: Peter Parks)

Title: Millions are heading home from the holiday to face snow and an Artic blast
Description: Some parts of the country will receive heavy lake-effect snow and others will see rain or dry weather with subfreezing temperatures. (Image credit: Robert F. Bukaty)

Title: Australia passes strict new social media bans for children
Description: Australian children will be banned from using some of the world's biggest social media sites under strict new laws passed by the country's parliament.

Title: The dynamic between Lebanon and Hezbollah is crucial for next steps in ceasefire deal
Description: The ceasefire deal between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon requires Hezbollah fighters to move North, away from the border with Israel. Lebanon's government is responsible for ensuring it happens.

Title: Iran claims that protestors of stringent hijab laws are in need of psychiatric help
Description: Two years after mass protests, women are still demonstrating against Iran's mandatory hijab law and clerical rule. Iran's government is saying the activists are in need of psychiatric help.

Title: A restored Notre Dame cathedral is unveiled days before its official reopening
Description: Notre Dame Cathedral has been closed to the public since a fire damaged the landmark in April 2019. (Image credit: Christophe Petit Tesson)

Title: British lawmakers push forward a divisive bill to legalize assisted dying
Description: In a historic vote, lawmakers advanced a bill that would grant the option of assisted dying to those in England and Wales with a terminal diagnosis and a life expectancy of six months or less. (Image credit: Dan Kitwood)

Title: People in Gaza face winter without enough food, shelter or security
Description: Colder weather and rains hit Gazans living in tents and bombed-out buildings. Most families don't have homes or shelter. We hear from families on the edge of survival.

Title: Books We Love is back. Here are some highlights. And, what to expect on Black Friday
Description: NPR staffers bring you more than 300 new book recommendations in the latest edition of Books We Love. Plus, what to expect from a record-breaking holiday spending season.

Title: Ireland votes in a close-run election where incumbents hope to cling on to power
Description: The parliamentary election will decide the next government, and will show whether Ireland bucks the global trend of incumbents being ousted by disgruntled voters. (Image credit: Niall Carson)

Title: 2 pediatricians answer your questions about traveling with kids over the holidays
Description: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with pediatricians Candice Jones and Jaime Friedman, who offer tips on how to travel with little ones. (Story aired on Morning Edition on Nov. 24, 2024.)

Title: Radio host remembers the person who cultivated her voice: her grandmother
Description: In this week's StoryCorps, Philadelphia radio host Cherri Gregg remembers her grandmother, Maryhall Fuller Robinson Snead, who helped her find her voice.

Title: Disappointed by this year's climate talks, Indigenous advocates look to Brazil in 2025
Description: Indigenous advocates called the final agreement in Azerbaijan 'drastically insufficient.' Now they're focusing on next year's global climate summit in Brazil where Indigenous participation is expected to be historic. (Image credit: Dominika Zarzycka/SOPA Images)

Title: Venezuela's opposition leader says Maduro is 'weaker than ever'
Description: From hiding, María Corina Machado says she'll continue to fight for Venezuelan democracy. (Image credit: Juan Barreto)

Title: The 2024 Atlantic hurricane season was the deadliest in nearly two decades
Description: The six-month season saw an above-average number of storms. Scientists say climate change is leading to more powerful and deadly hurricanes that can affect inland communities far from the coasts. (Image credit: NASA)

Title: How President-elect Donald Trump has garnered support in India
Description: In India, support for President-elect Donald Trump, is strong. In the hometown of Kamala Harris' mother, Indian men say they believe Trump will bring peace.

Title: The polls have opened in Ireland for the general election
Description: Voters are electing a new parliament and government. The race has tightened in recent days, and Sinn Fein -- a party with past links to Irish republican militants -- may still have a path to power.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Colder weather has hit Gazans living in tents and bombed-out buildings. This holiday shopping season is poised to break spending records. The influence of third party candidates seems to be waning.

Title: Who Invented Indian Butter Chicken? (Encore)
Description: In an episode we first brought you in March, we consider butter chicken. It is a much-loved Indian dish, both within that country and around the world. But who can claim they invented it? That question is the subject of a lawsuit. Our reporter tries to get to the bottom of butter chicken's origin and finds out that it is a journey through India's history.You can find celebrated Indian chef Madhur Jaffrey's recipe for butter chicken here. (Image credit: Arun Sankar)

Title: Democratic lawmakers report Thanksgiving bomb threats against their homes
Description: At least five Democratic members of Congress from Connecticut were targeted by bomb threats on Thursday. Police who responded said they found no evidence of explosives on the lawmakers' properties. (Image credit: J. Scott Applewhite)

Title: China sentences veteran journalist on espionage charges
Description: Longtime state media journalist Dong Yuyu met often with journalists and diplomats. His family believes he is now being persecuted for those exchanges. (Image credit: Dong Yuyu's family)

Title: Another winter arrives in Gaza, but flimsy tents are all people have
Description: People in Gaza have had to contest with Israeli airstrikes, hunger, armed gangs of looters and — now — a rainy winter without shelter.

Title: Vito the pug is the first of his breed to win National Dog Show's top prize
Description: Vito, a pug from Chapel Hill, N.C., beat out more than 1,900 dogs representing more than 200 breeds and varieties that competed in this year's event. (Image credit: NBC)

Title: Putin threatens Ukraine in remarks after former-Soviet states security summit
Description: Putin said his military may use another of its new hypersonic missiles to target government or official buildings in Kyiv, in response to Ukraine's continued use of American and British weapons. (Image credit: Ramil Sitdikov)

Title: Israel and Hezbollah have a ceasefire agreement. Here's what it says
Description: The ceasefire agreement between Hezbollah and Israel brokered by the United States and France was characterized by President Biden as an attempt to deliver a 'permanent cessation of hostilities.' (Image credit: Hussein Malla)

Title: A social media ban in Australia for children under 16 will be first in the world
Description: A social media ban for children under 16 will become first law in the world to levy fines on TikTok, Facebook, Snapchat, Reddit, X and Instagram for allowing youth accounts. (Image credit: Rick Rycroft)

Title: Lebanon says 2 hurt as Israeli troops fire after truce with Hezbollah
Description: The Israeli military said it had fired at people trying to return to certain areas of southern Lebanon on the second day of a ceasefire with the Hezbollah militant group. (Image credit: Hussein Malla)

Title: Come for the roller coaster, stay for the shops: Can malls be fun again?
Description: Mall of America's recipe for success includes an amusement park, pop-up stores, weddings and raves. Can local malls take a page from the country's largest shopping center? (Image credit: Jenn Ackerman for NPR)

Title: Feeding America on Thanksgiving: The challenges of addressing hunger in the U.S.
Description: As many sit down for a Thanksgiving feast, millions worry about where their next meal will come from. Feeding America CEO Claire Babineaux-Fontenot talks to NPR's Rob Schmitz about hunger in the U.S.

Title: Pause in Israel-Hezbollah war may build momentum toward a ceasefire in Gaza
Description: NPR's Rob Schmitz talks to Aaron David Miller at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace about prospects for replicating the Israel-Hezbollah truce with one in Gaza between Israel and Hamas.

Title: Concerned about arguments at Thanksgiving? NPR readers give tips to help
Description: Many topics have divided the nation recently. NPR asked readers for insights into how they handle divisive conversations over the holidays. Here are the tips they provided. (Image credit: Courtesy of Suzanne Sheuerman, Nicole Holliday, Barbara Schmidt, Marcella Yearwood and Debora Wagner)

Title: With ceasefire in place, Lebanese displaced by war are returning home
Description: Following the ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah, Lebanese refugees are returning to the south of the country to see if their homes are still standing.

Title: Tired. Damn tired.' Some Black women are processing the grief of a Kamala Harris loss
Description: Most Black women voters supported Kamala Harris in her presidential run against Donald Trump. Now some say they are pulling back, to rest and mourn. (Image credit: Ariel J. Cobbert for NPR)

Title: Life Kit: How to have difficult conversations during the holidays
Description: Sometimes holidays can lead to tense conversations -- if not everyone shares the same set of facts. NPR's Life Kit has some tips for navigating those conversations and setting the record straight.

Title: Abortion rights advocates are celebrating a victory in Wyoming
Description: A judge recently struck down Wyoming's ban on abortions, citing a state constitutional amendment championed by the state's Republicans in 2012.

Title: This Thanksgiving holiday is expected to be the busiest ever for air travel
Description: The TSA predicts 18 million people will pass through its checkpoints this week. We examine whether the Transportation Department's reform efforts are likely to endure into the Trump administration.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: After ceasefire, Lebanese are returning home. This Thanksgiving holiday is likely to be the busiest ever for air travel. Research shows even a short walk after a meal can be a big boost for health.

Title: Return to the Motherland or Illegal Land Transfer? Depends on Who You Ask (Encore)
Description: In an episode we first posted in January, we go to the West African country of Ghana. The Ghanaian government began encouraging people of African descent from around the world to move to the country in 2019, calling it the 'Year of Return'. They even created settlements for the people who took them up on the offer, giving out free land. But our correspondent talks to locals who say their farm land was stolen to give to foreigners.

Title: Trump transition says Cabinet picks, appointees were targeted by bomb threats, swatting attacks
Description: Among those targeted were New York Rep. Elise Stefanik, Trump's pick to serve as ambassador to the United Nations, and Matt Gaetz, Trump's initial pick to serve as attorney general. (Image credit: Alex Brandon)

Title: Court backs Texas over razor wire installed on US-Mexico border
Description: A federal appeals court Wednesday ruled that Border Patrol agents cannot cut razor wire that Texas installed on the U.S.-Mexico border in the town of Eagle Pass, Texas. (Image credit: Eric Gay)

Title: Teenage siblings break records passing the California bar exam
Description: Sophia Park has become the youngest person to pass the California bar exam at 17 years, 8 months old. She beats the record set by her brother Peter Park in 2023.

Title: People are heading back home in Lebanon on day one of Israel-Hezbollah ceasefire
Description: Under the deal, Israel will withdraw forces over 60 days as Lebanon's army takes control of territory near the border to ensure that Iran-backed Hezbollah does not rebuild its infrastructure.

Title: Meet the Canadian grandmother who is the newest women's world pushup record holder
Description: A 59-year-old grandmother of 12 took on the 60-minute challenge to push up her entire weight beyond the record 1,200 push ups already on the record books.

Title: Three Americans have been freed from prisons in China
Description: The Biden administration says the prisoners were all wrongfully held and that they are being reunited with their families for the first time in many years. They appear to be part of a prisoner swap.

Title: The uncertain fate of federal investigations into police misconduct
Description: Federal consent decrees can be a powerful legal tool to reform local police departments. They've stalled under Biden. What does Trump's second term mean for these court agreements?

Title: A dad, once held in immigration detention, shares hopes and fears for next 4 years
Description: NPR's Ari Shapiro checks in with a man he met in 2017 who was locked up in immigration detention. A judge finally let him return to his family, but he now wonders what the next four years will bring.

Title: The Israel-Hezbollah ceasefire is in effect in Lebanon
Description: A ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah militants in Lebanon took effect – and appears to be holding. Israeli troops are still present in many towns in southern Lebanon.

Title: Federal judge dismisses defamation lawsuit against Fox News
Description: A judge threw out a suit against Fox News by a former Trump supporter who said he got death threats when the network aired false conspiracy theories about his involvement in the Jan. 6 insurrection. (Image credit: Ted Shaffrey)

Title: The world welcomes the Israel-Hezbollah ceasefire, but worries remain
Description: Celebratory gunfire rang out in Beirut to mark the start of a ceasefire between Israel and the Iran-backed militant group Hezbollah to end almost 14 months of fighting. (Image credit: Anwar Amro)

Title: Is 'Do Unto Others' the way to bridge the political divide?
Description: On a Sunday in mid-July, Pastor Chris Morgan welcomed worshipers to Christ United Methodist Church in suburban Pittsburgh with a simple message.That Sunday was particularly difficult.A day earlier, a man had nearly assassinated then-candidate Donald Trump forty miles north in Butler. Morgan asked people to pray for Trump and those killed and injured in the shooting, and asked the congregation to pray for the family of the shooter.Morgan had already planned a sermon series, called Do Unto Others, to deal with the nation's — and his congregation's — political divisions ahead of Election Day. NPR's Frank Langfitt went to Christ Church the weekend before Election Day – and the weekend after – to see if the efforts there made a difference. As Americans ...

Title: How to watch Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, a tradition 100 years in the making
Description: Macy's is promising its largest Thanksgiving Day parade yet, exactly 100 years after the tradition first started. Here's a look at what to expect and how to watch. (Image credit: Eugene Gologursky)

Title: China has freed 3 Americans following an apparent prisoner swap deal with the U.S.
Description: In a statement, the State Department said all the 'wrongfully detained' Americans in China are now home. (Image credit: Jeff Chiu)

Title: A Remote Island Outpost that is Part of a Geopolitical Fight (Encore)
Description: In an episode we first brought you in April, we go to southeast Asia and the Spratly Islands. Ownership of those island are in dispute. This has been the case for hundreds of years, but tensions have been raised recently as China has tried to expand its claims in the remote area. We get a rare glimpse of one of the islands that has a Filipino community living on it. (Image credit: JAM STA ROSA)

Title: Over 500 fossilized poops show how dinosaurs came to rule the Earth
Description: Researchers reconstructed the Triassic food web using nothing but scat. (Image credit: Grzegorz Niedźwiedzki)

Title: Traffic citations against Miami Dolphins star Tyreek Hill are dropped
Description: Tyreek Hill of the Miami Dolphins was cited for careless driving and failure to wear a seat belt in September. The citations were dismissed after the officers involved did not appear in court. (Image credit: Rich Storry)

Title: More deals, more spending: What Black Friday has in store
Description: This holiday shopping season is poised to break spending records. A new survey finds people plan to spend $771 on average. (Image credit: Sarah Silbiger)

Title: Biden announced Israel-Hezbollah ceasefire -- a significant Middle East development
Description: NPR's Rob Schmitz talks to Jake Sullivan, President Biden's national security adviser, about the U.S. role in securing a ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon after months of fighting.

Title: Israel and Hezbollah ceasefire takes effect. And, TSA-approved Thanksgiving foods
Description: Israel and the Iran-backed militant group Hezbollah begins their ceasefire, but many remain displaced. And, if you are traveling for the holidays here are the foods you can bring through TSA. (Image credit: -)

Title: PHOTOS: A drone's eye view of 'foodscapes,' from cattle to soybeans to shrimp
Description: Traveling to 36 countries and 5 oceans, George Steinmetz (and his drones) take us on a food tour in his new book Feed the Planet: A Photographic Journey to the World's Food. (Image credit: George Steinmetz)

Title: Examining one year on from the only Israel-Hamas ceasefire in Gaza
Description: It's been one year since Israeli hostages and Palestinian prisoners were exchanged in a brief ceasefire negotiated in the Israel-Hamas war. We look at those released and the status of negotiations.

Title: A year ago this week Israel and Hamas agreed to a brief ceasefire in Gaza
Description: It's been one year since Israeli hostages and Palestinian prisoners were exchanged in a ceasefire negotiated in the Israel-Hamas war. We look at those released and the status of negotiations.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Ceasefire between Israel and Lebanon's Hezbollah militants has begun. Pakistan's security forces dispersed protesters in the capital. Trump tariffs aim to stop fentanyl from entering the U.S.

Title: California's attorney general prepares for legal battles with Trump administration
Description: NPR's A Martinez talks to California attorney general Rob Bonta about the incoming Trump administration. During Donald Trump's first term, the state sued the federal government more than 100 times.

Title: After months of deadly fighting, a ceasefire is reached in Israel-Hezbollah conflict
Description: The ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah has taken effect. The deal was negotiated by the U.S. and France, and was announced by President Biden after Israel's cabinet approved it.

Title: Pakistan ends lockdown of its capital after dispersing Imran Khan supporters
Description: The operation came hours after thousands of Khan supporters broke through a barrier of shipping containers blocking off Islamabad and clashed with security forces. (Image credit: Anjum Naveed)

Title: Khan's party suspends street protests after clashes with Pakistan's security forces
Description: Pakistan's jailed former Prime Minister Imran Khan has called off protests after a violent crackdown against his supporters in the capital Islamabad.

Title: The 'little r' racist idea that swung the election
Description: What lessons should we all be taking from the historic match-up between Donald Trump and Kamala Harris? New York Times political correspondent Astead Herndon says the big takeaway from this election isn't the divide between Republicans and Democrats, it's the divide between political elites and the American public. And he says it may be time to rethink our presumptions about how much voters care about representation.

Title: Brazil police report: Bolsonaro planned and participated in a 2022 coup plot
Description: The document describe the former president as one of the key leaders of the plot, and not a mere observer. (Image credit: Eraldo Peres)

Title: A Ceasefire Between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon
Description: Israel has agreed to a ceasefire with the militant group Hezbollah in Lebanon that hopes to bring an end to 13 months of fighting which has uprooted masses of civilians on both sides, and left immense destruction. We hear from NPR reporters on both sides of the conflict. Support NPR and get sponsor-free episodes of State of the World. Sign up for NPR+ at plus.npr.org Or donate to NPR this Giving Tuesday at donate.npr.org

Title: Angela Merkel recounts being the first and only in new memoir
Description: In her new memoir, Angela Merkel writes about the many dilemmas she had to navigate as Chancellor of Germany. Dilemmas her male colleagues never had to sweat. Like, can you wear a pantsuit instead of a skirt in the Bundestag, Germany's parliament? She decided the answer was, yes.Merkel is the only woman ever to rise to the most powerful political post in Germany. She served as chancellor from 2005 to 2021. Angela Merkel has gone toe-to-toe with world leaders like Vladimir Putin, led Germany through times of turmoil and become a role model for other women aspiring to positions of leadership. But her legacy is complex. She gets into all of this in her new memoir, 'Freedom.' For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+</em...

Title: Yes, get to the airport early. But here are some travel tips you might not know
Description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Scott Keyes, the founder of the travel app Going, about tips for what to do if your air travel doesn't go precisely as planned

Title: What Trump's approach to Iran might look like in his second term
Description: During his first term in the White House President trump took a hardline approach with Iran but is yet to say what his plans are for his second term.

Title: Israel agrees to ceasefire with Hezbollah
Description: Israel has agreed to a ceasefire with Hezbollah in Lebanon. It will be the first major ceasefire since the wars with Israel Gaza and Lebanon erupted last October.

Title: With a record number of international students in the U.S., Trump brings uncertainty
Description: Some schools and international students in the U.S. worry about what's to come in the incoming Trump administration. Meanwhile, a new report finds more international students in the U.S. than ever. (Image credit: Justin Sullivan)

Title: Netanyahu urges his cabinet to approve a ceasefire with Hezbollah
Description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is urging Israel's security Cabinet to approve a ceasefire with Hezbollah, paving the way for a possible pause in over a year of fighting with the Iran-backed group. (Image credit: -)

Title: Severe weather threatens Thanksgiving travel for millions as officials warn of delays
Description: Millions of drivers and air travelers may face severe weather and long lines over the next few days. More than 50,000 flights are expected to take off on Tuesday, one of the busiest travel days. (Image credit: Kamil Krzaczynski)

Title: A new congressman nabs his great-grandfather's old office after a little lobbying
Description: After he's sworn in, Rep.-elect Tom Barrett of Michigan will work in the Capitol office his great-grandfather once used. Rep. Louis Rabaut died in 1961, two decades before Barrett was born. (Image credit: Paul Sancya)

Title: Eyewitnesses in Gaza say Israel is using sniper drones to shoot Palestinians
Description: NPR has collected multiple eyewitness accounts about small, gun-carrying drones shooting — and sometimes killing — civilians in Gaza. Israel's military has not confirmed whether it uses sniper drones. (Image credit: Dawoud Abo Alkas)

Title: How Trump wants to cut spending. And, possible Israel-Hezbollah ceasefire deal
Description: President-elect Donald Trump wants to use a presidential impoundment to make big cuts to government spending. And, what could block a ceasefire deal between Israel and Hezbollah. (Image credit: -)

Title: Efforts continue to reach a diplomatic resolution to the conflict in Lebanon
Description: Is a pause in the fighting between Israel and Hezbollah possible? Diplomats in Lebanon and Israel say a deal is close. Are the sticking points surmountable?

Title: The price America paid for its first big immigration crackdown
Description: The Chinese Exclusion Act was the first significant crackdown on immigration in American history. We explore the factors that led to the Act and examine what happened to the economy after it passed. (Image credit: Thure de Thulstrup)

Title: Trump has promised lower taxes. These are 3 ways it could impact you
Description: From 'no tax on tips' to Social Security, Donald Trump has made a range of promises about the taxes Americans will pay. We take a look at three changes we could see in the months ahead. (Image credit: Allison Robbert)

Title: Dirt-cheap toys imported into U.S. can be dangerous, group says. Here's what to know
Description: We rarely come out and say, 'You should not do this.' But this is one of the exceptions,' consumer advocate Teresa Murray says, warning against the lure of rock-bottom prices from unfamiliar sellers. (Image credit: Ya-Huei Laura Lee)

Title: Supporters of ousted Pakistani leader Imran Khan clash with police
Description: Protesters surged into the capital Islamabad -- amid gunfire and teargas -- as they demanded the release of former Prime Minister Imran Khan.

Title: Mohammad Rasoulof left Iran after making his most daring film
Description: Dissident filmmaker Mohammad Rasoulof talks about how he escaped Iran on foot after making his new political thriller, The Seed of the Sacred Fig.

Title: Angela Merkel and the future of NATO under a second Trump term
Description: Former German Chancellor Angela Merkel says she had to consider whether she is a 'feminist.' She joined NPR's Mary Louise Kelly to discuss her new memoir, Freedom. (Image credit: Mehmet Kaman)

Title: Gospel-focused racial reconciliation in the Deep South
Description: Two former leaders of the Southern Baptist Convention, one Black and one white, want to bridge the Deep South's racial divide with faith-based discussions in cities once active in the slave trade. (Image credit: Annie Flanagan for NPR)

Title: Texas officials aim to help Trump deport millions of undocumented migrants
Description: Texas is preparing to help Donald Trump carry out his plan to deport undocumented immigrants. The state offered the incoming president 1,400-acres on the border to prepare for mass deportations.

Title: A look at a pilot program in Georgia that uses 'jailbots' to track inmates
Description: A county jail in Georgia is testing out AI equipped rolling robots to help monitor inmates. Supporters say it helps with staff shortages, while opponents say it could present a privacy violation.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Diplomats say ceasefire between Israel and Lebanon may be imminent. President-elect Trump has a plan to make big cuts in government spending. Conservative sets sights on reshaping American culture.

Title: Walmart becomes latest -- and biggest -- company to roll back its DEI policies
Description: Conservative groups have filed lawsuits against workplace diversity initiatives that prioritize historically marginalized groups. (Image credit: Steven Senne)

Title: Supporters of ousted Pakistani leader clash with police in Islamabad
Description: Police used tear gas to disperse the crowds and at least one person has died in clashes. (Image credit: Maaz Awan)

Title: Was the Infowars auction fair? A judge wants to hear arguments in December
Description: The Onion's bid came out on top, but a bankruptcy judge must sign off on the sale. Conspiracy theorist Alex Jones and the losing bidder says the process was 'rigged' against them. (Image credit: Mario Tama)

Title: Trump threatens Canada, Mexico, China with tariffs
Description: He said the countries weren't doing enough to control the flow of illegal drugs, especially fentanyl, and migrants across the border. (Image credit: Brandon Bell)

Title: Lebanon's first responders say Israeli strikes target them as they work to save lives
Description: More than 200 emergency and medical workers have been killed since last October, Lebanon's health ministry says. Many believe Israel's military is targeting them in its war against Hezbollah. (Image credit: Ali Khara for NPR)

Title: Menendez brothers appear virtually in court for next steps in resentencing hearing
Description: Lyle and Erik Menendez appeared virtually in court as a judge decided next steps in their resentencing hearing, which is more uncertain now that the DA who recommended it has been voted out of office.

Title: A ceasefire deal could be close as Israel-Hezbollah violence continues
Description: Israeli airstrikes shook Southern Beirut Monday and Hezbollah has continued to fire hundreds of rockets into Israel. Amid this violence, there are some signals of a diplomatic deal in the works.

Title: The Consequences of Refusing to Serve in Israel's Military
Description: Israel has mandatory military services for citizens over the age of eighteen that meet certain requirements, and refusing to serve, which has always been controversial is even more contentious now that the country is fighting in Gaza and Lebanon. We meet one young person choosing to go to jail rather than serve in the military. Support NPR and get sponsor-free episodes of State of the World. Sign up for NPR+ at plus.npr.org Or donate to NPR this Giving Tuesday at donate.npr.org

Title: Prosecutors file motion to dismiss Jan. 6 case against Trump
Description: The move was widely expected after Trump's election victory, and is in line with longstanding Justice Department policy that says a sitting president cannot be indicted or tried on criminal charges. (Image credit: Saul Loeb)

Title: Macy's says an employee hid as much as $154 million in expenses
Description: The employee 'intentionally made erroneous accounting accrual entries' to hide millions of dollars, Macy's said. The error forced the company to delay reporting its third quarter results. (Image credit: Justin Sullivan)

Title: Ocean explorers hoped they photographed Amelia Earhart's plane. Turns out it's a rock
Description: Earhart, her navigator and their plane disappeared during their attempted 1937 circumnavigation of the globe. A deep sea exploration company thought it might have solved the mystery, but it lives on. (Image credit: Uncredited)

Title: The man who helped roll back abortion rights now wants to 'crush liberal dominance'
Description: Leonard Leo of the Federalist Society helped overturn abortion rights. He spoke to Morning Edition about his plans to disrupt Hollywood, Silicon Valley and other perceived centers of liberal thinking through the Teneo Network. (Image credit: Carolyn Kaster/AP)

Title: After 15 years, Megan Atherton reunites with her 'Unsung Hero'
Description: A special reunion conversation between Megan Atherton and the woman who changed the course of her life. (Image credit: Megan Atherton)

Title: Plastic waste is everywhere. Countries have one more chance to agree on a solution
Description: Negotiations over a U.N. treaty to cut plastics have been bogged down. Environmental groups blame the oil and gas industry. (Image credit: Christopher Furlong)

Title: Romania in shock after far-right populist enters presidential election's runoff
Description: Romania's political landscape is reeling after a little-known, far-right populist secured the first round in the presidential election, going from an obscure candidate to beating the incumbent prime minister. (Image credit: Alexandru Dobre)

Title: U.N. report: A woman or girl is killed every 10 minutes by a family member, partner
Description: A U.N. report shows rates are rising despite efforts for more severe penalties for targeted murders of women. The majority of female homicides are committed by an intimate partner or a family member.

Title: U.N. report: A woman or girl is killed every 10 minutes by her intimate partner
Description: A U.N. report shows rates are rising despite efforts for more severe penalties for targeted murders of women. The majority of female homicides are committed by an intimate partner or a family member.

Title: Some young Israelis choose to go to jail rather than fight in Gaza
Description: Military service is mandatory in Israel, but the war in Gaza has led some young Israelis to reject this obligation. A small number of young Israelis after choosing jail over the draft.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: President-elect Donald Trump announces more Cabinet picks. U.N. report says a woman or girl was killed every 10 minutes in 2023. Climate conference ends with a deal to help developing countries.

Title: Adultery is no longer illegal in New York
Description: It was considered a Class B misdemeanor, which carries a jail sentence of up to three months. (Image credit: Angela Weiss)

Title: Foreign ministers meet in Italy for the last G7 of the Biden administration
Description: Foreign ministers from the world's leading industrialized nations are meeting Monday, with a certain pressure to advance diplomatic efforts ahead of the new U.S. administration taking over. (Image credit: Andrew Medichini)

Title: New Zealanders help save about 30 whales after a pod strands on a beach
Description: New Zealand is a whale stranding hotspot. It's often not clear why they happen but the island nation's geography is believed to be a factor. (Image credit: Nikki Hartley)

Title: Should sex abuse evidence set the Menendez brothers free? A judge will decide.
Description: A judge will decide Monday whether new evidence warrants a re-examination of the convictions of Erik and Lyle Menendez in the shotgun murders of their parents 30 years ago. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Uruguay's leftist opposition candidate becomes country's new president
Description: The election was free of the anti-establishment fury that has vaulted populist outsiders to power elsewhere, like the United States and neighboring Argentina. (Image credit: Natacha Pisarenko)

Title: 2 Dartmouth fraternity members and a sorority have been charged in death of a student
Description: The Alpha Phi sorority and two members of Beta Alpha Omega have been charged after a student was found dead in a river after attending an off-campus party where alcohol was allegedly served to minors. (Image credit: Charles Krupa)

Title: Israeli strike kills Lebanese soldier as Hezbollah fires rockets at Israel
Description: An Israeli strike on a Lebanese army center on Sunday killed one soldier and wounded 18 others, the Lebanese military said. (Image credit: Oded Balilty/AP)

Title: Trump announces three medical doctors as his picks for the FDA, CDC and Surgeon-General
Description: President-elect Donald Trump announced three medical doctors as his picks to lead the FDA, CDC and to serve as surgeon general. NPR's Pien Huang discusses his picks.

Title: Israeli strike targets the heart of Beirut, killing 20 people
Description: There was a rare airstrike in the heart of Lebanon's capital Saturday. Israeli media say it was targeting a Hezbollah leader.

Title: Anti-Trump Republicans find themselves in a political no man's land after Trump's win
Description: With some contacting attorneys and others looking to move out of the country, anti-Trump Republicans are trying to figure out what's next after betting against the president-elect. (Image credit: Ali Khaligh)

Title: Russia is using new technology in its attacks on Ukraine
Description: Attacks between Ukraine and Russia are escalating, with Russia using what it describes as new missile technology.

Title: As Israel cuts ties with UNRWA, Palestinian refugees could lose vital services
Description: Israel has voted to end cooperation with UNRWA, the United Nations agency providing aid to Palestinian refugees. The move threatens key services for hundreds of thousands of refugees in the West Bank.

Title: San Francisco's incoming mayor has never held public office. That's part of his appeal
Description: San Francisco's new mayor, Daniel Lurie, has never held public office before. What does his win indicate about how voters are feeling about homelessness and other big issues the city is facing?

Title: Louisiana's faith groups are divided over a state law but work together for the community
Description: In Louisiana, religious leaders disagree over a state law that requires every public school classroom to display the Ten Commandments but still work together to address community needs.

Title: A photographer's devastating documentation of El Salvador's civil war in the 1980s
Description: In Legacy of Lies, El Salvador 1981-1984, photojournalist Robert Nickelsberg documents how U.S. foreign policy fueled a violent 13-year civil war in El Salvador. (Image credit: Robert Nickelsberg)

Title: With talks teetering, climate negotiators struck a controversial $300 billion deal
Description: Representatives of developing countries and climate activists were furious over the outcome, saying $300 billion annually from industrialized countries is far short of what vulnerable nations need to better protect themselves from climate change. (Image credit: Sean Gallup/Getty Images)

Title: Now in overtime, UN climate talks continue
Description: UN climate negotiations are in overtime in Azerbiajan as countries scramble to land a deal on how to finance the damages brought on by climate change. The impacts often are felt most by poor countries that have contributed the least to global warming.

Title: A program in D.C. raised the wages of child care workers. How's it going now?
Cousins divided on abortion find ways to support each other
Description: One believes in total abortion rights. The other is against abortion in all circumstances. They're cousins, as close as sisters, and have come together with understanding on this truly divisive topic.

Title: Alcohol poisoning deaths in Laos renew concerns about methanol. Here's what to know
Description: The U.S., Australia and U.K. have issued warnings for travelers in Vang Vieng after several tourists died in a suspected methanol poisoning outbreak. (Image credit: Anupam Nath)

Title: Winter storms sweep across the U.S. while a new system is expected for Thanksgiving
Description: A major storm dropped more snow and record rain in California, while on the opposite side of the country blizzard or winter storm warnings were in effect Saturday. (Image credit: Noah Berger)

Title: NATO head and Trump meet in Florida for talks on global security
Description: U.S. President-elect Donald Trump and the head of NATO, Mark Rutte, met on Friday in Palm Beach for talks on global security, the military alliance said Saturday. (Image credit: Alex Brandon)

Title: What Trump's pick for secretary of defense could mean for inclusivity in the military
Description: The Trump administration nominee for secretary of defense calls women in combat roles a mistake. Critics fear it's yet another signal that policies that engage with a changing America could be on the chopping block.

Title: Biden administration urges states to move forward with Colorado River sharing agreement
Description: The seven states that share the Colorado River have a 2026 deadline for a new sharing agreement. The Biden administration this week encouraged them to hurry, in an apparent attempt to limit the incoming Trump administration's influence.

Title: Janet Martin, Mayor of the Armitage Brown Line station, retires after 29 years
Description: Janet Martin, aka the Mayor of Armitage Brown Line Station, is retiring from the Chicago Transit Authority after a 29-year career marked with kindness.

Title: Bringing Thanksgiving food on a plane? Here is what you should know
Description: Thanksgiving favorites such as mac and cheese, turkey and casseroles can be brought through TSA checkpoints. But cranberry sauce, maple syrup and gravy must go in checked baggage, the agency says. (Image credit: Transportation Security Administration)

Title: South Africa's illegal gold miners are locked in an underground standoff with police
Description: Surviving on a diet of toothpaste and toilet paper, South Africa's notorious 'zama-zama' illegal miners continue a weeks-long standoff with police in the darkness of a disused gold mine. (Image credit: Shiraaz Mohamed)

Title: Trump's deportation vow alarms Texas construction industry
Description: Texas builders warn mass deportations of undocumented migrants could devastate the construction industry, threatening housing and infrastructure work in one of the nation's fastest-growing states. (Image credit: John Moore)

Title: At least 11 killed in Israeli strikes in Beirut as diplomats push for cease-fire
Description: The strikes were the fourth on Beirut in less than a week. The escalation comes after a U.S. envoy traveled to the region this week in an attempt to broker a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah. (Image credit: Hassan Ammar)

Title: Atmospheric rivers aren't new. Why does it feel like we're hearing about them more?
Description: In recent years, 'atmospheric river' has become used much more frequently in scientific papers and in media coverage. According to experts who study climate and weather, a few reasons may explain why. (Image credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images)

Title: NATO and Ukraine to hold emergency talks after Russia's attack with new missile
Description: NATO and Ukraine will hold emergency talks Tuesday after Russia attacked the city of Dnipro with an experimental, hypersonic ballistic missile that escalated the nearly 33-month-old war. (Image credit: Vyacheslav Prokofyev/AP)

Title: Trump names former Texas state Rep. Scott Turner to lead Housing and Urban Development
Description: HUD is bracing for possible budget cuts, something the first Trump administration proposed but was unable to get through Congress. Other changes could restrict who gets rental aid. (Image credit: Alastair Pike)

Title: The ICC's arrest warrant for Israel's Netanyahu highlights international divisions
Description: The International Criminal Court's decision to issue arrest warrants for Israel's prime minister, its former defense minister and a senior military leader of Hamas has exposed deep global divisions.

Title: Palestinian olive farmers face violence from settlers and security forces
Description: Olive harvesting in the West Bank has become increasingly dangerous as Palestinian farmers face a rise in violence by Israeli settlers and security forces.

Title: Mass deportations would hurt families and Texas' construction industry, many say
Description: The migrant workforce is vital to construction across Texas. Now, the industry is bracing for Trump's expected crackdown on illegal immigration, including plans to carry out mass deportations.

Title: A Relationship Surviving 1,000 Days of War
Description: It has been over a thousand days since Russia began it's full-scale invasion of Ukraine. The war has had huge geopolitical ramifications, but it has also has affected the lives of millions of ordinary people. Our correspondent in Kyiv tells us how the one couple in Ukraine has weathered the conflict. (Image credit: Claire Harbage)

Title: Wisconsin kayaker who faked his death has resurfaced in Europe after elaborate plot
Description: Wisconsin authorities say they have not yet issued a warrant for Ryan Borgwardt, who is believed to be somewhere in Eastern Europe. But that can change if he does not cooperate and return home soon. (Image credit: Green Lake County Sheriff's Office via AP)

Title: Jonathan Majors and ex-girlfriend Grace Jabbari settle assault and defamation case
Description: In a civil lawsuit this spring, the actor's former girlfriend alleged a 'pattern of pervasive domestic abuse' in addition to defamation. Her legal team said the suit has been settled. (Image credit: Richard Shotwell)

Title: University of Texas, MIT and others announce free tuition for some undergraduates
Description: Nearly half a dozen institutions of higher education announced plans this week to make tuition free for undergraduates whose families make below a certain income threshold, starting in fall 2025.

Title: Judge indefinitely postpones sentencing in Trump's hush money case
Description: The decision to indefinitely adjourn next week's sentencing date comes several days after both lawyers agreed that a stay would help sort out unprecedented legal questions. (Image credit: Brandon Bell)

Title: 6 tourists in Laos have died after drinking tainted alcohol
Description: Tourists from the U.S., Australia, Denmark and the U.K. have died. A tourism police officer said a 'number of people' had been detained in the case but that no charges have yet been filed. (Image credit: Anupam Nath)

Title: Trump's new pick for attorney general. And, Russia's message to NATO countries
Description: President-elect Donald Trump picks Pam Bondi as attorney general after Matt Gaetz withdraws from consideration. And, Putin says Russia tested a new intermediate-range ballistic missile on Ukraine. (Image credit: Mandel Ngan)

Title: You can sword-fight at this club. But no politics allowed
Description: At the Pittsburgh Sword Fighters club, members are asked to leave their politics at the door, a rule that has led to closer relationships and more learning from one another. (Image credit: Justin Merriman for NPR)

Title: President-elect set to shape 'Trump judiciary' for next generation
Description: Legal experts predict President-elect Donald Trump will move quickly next year to cement and extend his legacy in appointing federal judges. (Image credit: Tasos Katopodis)

Title: Former Google CEO Eric Schmidt discusses the DOJ move to have Google sell off Chrome
Description: Michel Martin asks former Google CEO Eric Schmidt about the government's move to separate Google from its Chrome browser and the future of artificial intelligence as envisioned in the book 'Genesis.' (Image credit: David Levenson)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Trump picks Pam Bondi as nominee for AG after Matt Gaetz withdraws, Russia's Putin takes an even more aggressive stance, and looking the connection between climate change and atmospheric river storms.

Title: United Nations nuclear agency again condemns Iran for failing to fully cooperate
Description: The resolution comes after the agency said Iran has defied demands to rein in its nuclear program and has increased its stockpile of uranium enriched to near weapons-grade levels. (Image credit: Heinz-Peter Bader)

Title: Alabama carries out nation's 3rd nitrogen gas execution
Description: An Alabama man convicted in the 1994 killing of a hitchhiker cursed at the prison warden shortly before he was put to death Thursday evening in the nation's third execution using nitrogen gas. (Image credit: Kim Chandler)

Title: Trump names former Florida AG Pam Bondi as his new pick for U.S. attorney general
Description: After former Rep. Matt Gaetz withdrew from consideration, President-elect Donald Trump named Pam Bondi, a former attorney general of Florida, as his next pick for U.S. attorney general. (Image credit: Mandel Ngan)

Title: Police report gives details, timeline of the sexual assault claim against Pete Hegseth
Description: The woman who accused then-Fox News host of sexual assault in 2017 said that she 'remembered saying 'no' a lot,' according to a police report. Hegseth is President-elect Donald Trump's choice for Secretary of Defense. (Image credit: Google Maps /Screenshot by NPR)

Title: At sheriff's request, the FBI is investigating the death of a Black man found hanging
Description: The FBI Is investigating the death of a Black man found hanging at an abandoned home in rural Alabama after his family doubted the sheriff's conclusion that it was suicide.

Title: What we know about the experimental missile Russia fired at a Ukrainian city today
Description: Russia fired an experimental missile at a city in eastern Ukraine today, inflicting damage and injuries. Exactly what type of missile is this and what message is Russia trying to send?

Title: Israel's ambassador to the UN weighs in on ICC's warrants for Netanyahu and Gallant
Description: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with Israel's Ambassador to the UN, Danny Danon, about the International Criminal Court's arrest warrants for PM Benjamin Netanyahu and former defense Minister Yoav Gallant.

Title: Communities in North Carolina are still without drinkable water 8 weeks after Helene
Description: More than a dozen water systems in North Carolina are still impaired eight weeks after they were damaged by the remnants of Hurricane Helene. People are adjusting to life without drinking water.

Title: A closer look at how armed gangs steal tons of aid in Gaza
Description: Gangs of armed looters are stealing the little aid trickling into Gaza as people starve, and it's happening under Israel's surveillance.

Title: In Gaza Organized Gangs Make a Bad Situation Even Worse
Description: Israel has been accused of using starvation in Gaza as a weapon of war. It's a charge the government denies, however aid groups say too little food is being allowed into Gaza. And making the problem even worse, armed gangs are looting much of the aid that is coming in. We hear more about the issue and what Israel is doing about it. For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

Title: What is the ICC and can it really arrest Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu?
Description: The ICC also issued warrants for Yoav Gallant, former Israeli defense minister, and Hamas leader Muhammad Deif. But it doesn't have an enforcement mechanism and relies on states to make the arrests. (Image credit: Laurens Van Putten)

Title: Former Brazilian president indicted over alleged coup plot
Description: Brazil's former President Jair Bolsonaro and several others have been charged with attempting to overthrow incoming government of President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva in 2022. (Image credit: Andre Penner)

Title: Russia launched an experimental ballistic missile at Ukraine, the U.S. says
Description: Ukraine raised alarm suggesting Russia may have used an intercontinental ballistic missile to hit the city of Dnipro, but the U.S. National Security Council does not believe it was an ICBM. (Image credit: Latin America News Agency)

Title: Former Rep. Matt Gaetz withdraws as attorney general nominee
Description: Allegations of sex trafficking and drug use threatened to derail Matt Gaetz's nomination as attorney general. (Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)

Title: This year's FAFSA is officially open. Early review says it's 'a piece of cake'
Description: The FAFSA form is now open to students hoping to get help paying for college in the 2025-26 academic year. Students can expect a much smoother process compared to the last cycle. (Image credit: Seth Wenig)

Title: The International Criminal Court has issued arrest warrants for Netanyahu and Gallant
Description: The International Criminal Court issued arrest warrants on Thursday for Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former Defense Minister Yoav Gallant, for alleged war crimes in the Gaza Strip. (Image credit: Laurens Van Putten)

Title: International Criminal Court issues arrest warrants for Netanyahu, Gallant
Description: The court issued arrest warrants for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former Defense Minister Yoav Gallant over alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity in the Gaza Strip.

Title: The Mother of Thanksgiving
Description: The Thanksgiving story most of us hear is about friendship and unity. And that's what Sarah Josepha Hale had on her mind when she sat down to write a letter to President Lincoln in 1863, deep into the Civil War. Hale had already spent years campaigning for a national day of thanksgiving, using her platform as editor of one the country's most widely-read magazines and writing elected officials to argue that Americans urgently needed a national story. But she'd gotten nowhere – until now.Five days after reading her letter, Lincoln declared Thanksgiving a national holiday. At the time, no one was talking about Pilgrims and Native Americans. But that too would change.Today on the show: a Thanksgiving story you may not have heard, how it happened, and what it leaves out.

Title: How this couple managed to stay together when one embraced QAnon conspiracy theories
Description: A California couple's relationship was tested when one of them started embracing QAnon conspiracy theories. Find out how they managed to stay together — and find common ground.

Title: How will Trump's second term impact the role of women in the military
Description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with U.S. Special Operations veteran Jessica Yahn about the impact of anticipated cuts to women's combat roles in the military during Trump's second presidential term.

Title: Chinese vessel under investigation after 2 data cables found cut in the Baltic Sea
Description: Germany's defense minister said damage to two data cables in the Baltic Sea appeared to be acts of sabotage. Several European countries have launched investigations.

Title: To hit deep inside Russia, Ukraine has built its own drones
Description: President Biden has now given Ukraine permission to use U.S. ballistic missiles inside Russia. While it was waiting, Ukraine built its own drones that can strike far across the border. (Image credit: Efrem Lukatsky)

Title: A barbershop in Denver offers formerly incarcerated people a second chance
Description: The guy who ran the Floyd's Barbershop chain has a new barbershop that employs formerly incarcerated people. His goal is to help them stay free, and help customers get over bias.

Title: Documentary 'No Other Land' looks at Palestinians forced from homes in the West Bank
Description: The documentary 'No Other Land' by a Palestinian-Israeli collective looks at rural Palestinian communities in the Israeli occupied West Bank being forced out of their homes by the Israeli military.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Two data cables have been damaged in the Baltic Sea, President-elect Trump picks Matthew Whitaker as ambassador to NATO, and Republicans win big in a relatively high-turnout election.

Title: A duct-taped banana sells for $6.2 million at an art auction
Description: A piece of conceptual art consisting of a simple banana, duct-taped to a wall, sold for $6.2 million at an auction Wednesday, with the winning bid coming from a prominent cryptocurrency entrepreneur. (Image credit: Eduardo Munoz Alvarez)

Title: U.S. charges Indian billionaire with defrauding investors, hiding bribery scheme
Description: One of the world's richest people has been indicted on charges he duped investors in a massive solar energy project in India by concealing that it was being facilitated by an alleged bribery scheme. (Image credit: Ajit Solanki)

Title: Clam farmers continue to struggle after Hurricane Helene
Description: Florida has lost much of its clam industry from hurricanes over the past year. Clam farmers say it will be a while until they can recover their losses.

Title: Israeli destruction makes large parts of south Lebanon 'uninhabitable'
Description: Israel's war against Hezbollah has driven hundreds of thousand of civilians from their homes in southern Lebanon. Satellite data and eye witness testimony indicate the scale of the destruction.

Title: Sanctuary city' ordinance would protect undocumented immigrants living in L.A.
Description: Los Angeles on Tuesday approved a so-called 'sanctuary city' ordinance aimed at protecting undocumented immigrants from potential deportation.

Title: Witnesses say Israel is using sniper drones in Gaza and they're shooting civilians
Description: Last week British surgeon Nizam Mamode testified in front of a committee in the U.K. Parliament. Dr. Mamode had recently returned from working at a hospital in Central Gaza. He told parliamentary members what he witnessed, including drones that would come down and 'pick off civilians, children. And we had description after description. This is not, you know, an occasional thing. This was day after day after day.' For months, NPR has been collecting eyewitness accounts from Gaza that corroborate Dr. Mamode's testimony, saying the Israeli military has been using sniper drone technology and that they're not just shooting enemies, but also civilians.|For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at <a hre...

Title: How the European Union is preparing for the second Trump presidency
Description: Members of the European Union Are Preparing With Caution and, At Times, Keenness for the Second Trump Presidency.

Title: Philadelphia's Chinatown says the proposed 76ers arena would destroy the neighborhood
Description: The Philadelphia 76ers want to build a billion-dollar arena in the city's downtown. Residents and business owners in nearby Chinatown say the project will destroy the thriving neighborhood.

Title: Sabotage suspected after undersea cables damaged in the Baltic Sea
Description: A Chinese cargo ship has been stopped off the coast of Denmark. Officials are investigating it for severing underwater telecommunications cables connecting a handful of northern European countries.

Title: A Chinese cargo ship severed underwater telecom cables in the Baltic Sea
Description: A Chinese cargo ship has been stopped off the coast of Denmark. Officials are investigating it for severing underwater telecommunications cables connecting a handful of northern European countries.

Title: Federal courts trumpet steps to protect workers after #MeToo movement
Description: The federal courts say they have taken 'extensive' steps to protect workers from abuse, discrimination and harassment since the rise of the #MeToo movement, but critics say many workers don't trust the internal system for reporting complaints. (Image credit: Drew Angerer)

Title: The International Space Station adjusts its orbit to avoid space debris
Description: There are at least 19,000 pieces of space debris in Earth's orbit, not including active satellites, that the U.S is monitoring. (Image credit: Roscosmos Space Agency Press Service)

Title: Violent Attacks in China Raise Difficult Questions
Description: A series of deadly attacks within China in recent weeks have killed dozens and left people uneasy. Those who carried out the attacks have been seemingly ordinary people who authorities say became disgruntled or unhappy. Our correspondent brings us to the site of one recent attacks and says these incidents are raising difficult questions about society and the government.

Title: A man has been convicted of murder in the killing of Laken Riley
Description: The case over the killing of a Georgia nursing student fueled the national debate over immigration during this year's presidential race. (Image credit: Hyosub Shin/AP)

Title: Trump picks Matthew Whitaker for ambassador to NATO
Description: President-elect Donald Trump tapped Matthew Whitaker as his ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which Trump has long criticized for taking advantage of U.S. defense spending. (Image credit: Michael Ciaglo)

Title: NFL kickers are better than ever from long distance, and that's changing football
Description: Field goals of 50 yards or longer used to be a rare thing in the NFL. But this season, kickers are hitting them at a record 72% clip — and head coaches are trying them far more often than ever before. (Image credit: Ron Jenkins)

Title: How a Sabrina Carpenter song led to a priest's demotion for mishandling church funds
Description: Officials say Monsignor Jamie Gigantiello was disciplined for mishandling $1.9 million in parish funds. He faced scrutiny last year for letting Carpenter film a music video at his Brooklyn church.

Title: Is Trump pick Pete Hegseth ready to run Defense? A former defense secretary weighs in
Description: Former Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel says 'a lack of any government experience is an issue' when leading the largest institution in the world. (Image credit: Evan Vucci)

Title: U.S. Embassy in Kyiv shuts down due to Russian air attack threat
Description: Russia promised a response to President Joe Biden's decision to let Ukraine strike targets on Russian soil with U.S.-made missiles. (Image credit: Efrem Lukatsky)

Title: Rust' premieres three years after a fatal on-set shooting
Description: Three years ago, cinematographer Halyna Hutchins was killed when a gun held by Alec Baldwin went off on set. Her husband settled a wrongful death suit to become a producer of the film, which premieres in Poland on Wednesday. (Image credit: Andres Leighton)

Title: Oarfish keep washing ashore in California. Folklore suggests that could be a bad omen
Description: A deep sea oarfish washed up in Southern California. Japanese folklore suggests seeing the rare fish is a bad omen, some accounts say. (Image credit: Alison Laferriere)

Title: SS United States, record-setting ocean liner, makes its final voyage
Description: The SS United States, a record-breaking 1950s ocean liner, may soon sail from Philadelphia to the Gulf. NPR explored this ship, a relic of the grand liners that once connected North America with Europe. (Image credit: Stephen Mallon for NPR)

Title: Eyewitnesses say Israel is using sniper drones in Gaza
Description: Israel is reportedly using a new kind of weapon in Gaza: small drones that carry guns and fire at targets like snipers. Eyewitnesses in Gaza say these drones have killed many civilians.

Title: Wildfires in eastern U.S. put strain on fire departments
Description: The eastern U.S. is dealing with record numbers of wildfires. It's a new problem for many communities. Fire departments are struggling to cope with a situation experts say may become the 'new normal.'

Title: People hate that about us.' Pittsburgh politician and radio host forge unlikely bond
Description: The country is at odds over how to approach intractable issues such as crime, addiction and homelessness. In Pittsburgh, an unlikely pair of firebrands is talking across the political divide.

Title: Here's what happened in Gaza after biggest looting of U.N. food aid in recent memory
Description: Armed gangs attacked a convoy of more than 100 trucks of United Nations food aid, as humanitarian groups call on Israel to do more to secure aid routes and as people across Gaza go hungry.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Congress grills FEMA head over disaster response, Trump picks business executive Linda McMahon to lead Education Department, and social media app Bluesky sees huge growth after Trump's election win.

Title: Congress grills head of FEMA following request for additional disaster funding
Description: Members of Congress grilled the head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency Tuesday. The Biden administration wants additional disaster funding after this year's onslaught of natural disasters.

Title: A surge in mass attacks has killed dozens in China in recent months
Description: Dozens of people have been killed in China in the past three months in a series of mass attacks. The latest on Tuesday saw primary school students injured by a car as they arrived for classes. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Residents in Haiti's capital stand with police in a battle to repel gang attack
Description: Residents have been angered by the latest gang attacks. Violence forced Haiti's main airport to shut down last week after the country swore in a new prime minister. (Image credit: Odelyn Joseph)

Title: Trump picks business executive Linda McMahon to lead the Education Department
Description: McMahon is a professional wrestling business magnate and co-chair of President-elect Donald Trump's transition team. She has limited experience working with K-12 public schools. (Image credit: Matt Rourke)

Title: The fight for Alex Jones' Infowars company heats up as Jones sues to hold on
Description: The Onion thought it had the last laugh when it was named the winning bidder after last week's bankruptcy auction. Now, Jones says that bid was 'fake dollars' and wants a judge to disqualify it (Image credit: David J. Phillip)

Title: Neighbors come together across small Washington county to confront political divide
Description: In the Pacific Northwest, a group of neighbors meets every week to discuss their disagreements. While they often differ on political views, many share a love for their region and close-knit community.

Title: Witnesses say Israel is using sniper drones in Gaza and they're shooting civilians
Description: Eyewitnesses in Gaza say that Israel's military is using guns attached to drones to carry out attacks

Title: Ukraine carries out first attacks on Russian territory using U.S. ballistic missiles
Description: For the first time, Ukraine has fired U.S. ballistic missiles into Russia as part of heavy ongoing fighting. Russia is expressing strong opposition and says this marks an escalation in the war.

Title: Is Israel Using New, Deadly Military Technology in Gaza?
Description: NPR has been collecting eyewitness accounts from Gaza that indicate Israel is using a new type of drone. One that has a gun attached that can shoot people remotely. We hear how Israel is using it in Gaza and what this technology could mean for the future of warfare. (Image credit: Eyad Baba)

Title: A GOP lawmaker introduces a Capitol bathroom rule before her trans colleague arrives
Description: South Carolina Rep. Nancy Mace says the resolution aims to protect women's rights. Democratic Rep.-elect Sarah McBride, the first out trans person elected to Congress, has slammed it as a distraction.

Title: Manhattan prosecutors ask for additional pause in Trump hush-money criminal case
Description: Manhattan prosecutors are asking for a further pause in the criminal trial against President-elect Donald Trump in order to give both sides time to weigh the unprecedented nature of the situation. (Image credit: Spencer Platt)

Title: A 'bomb cyclone' is expected to hit Pacific Northwest. Here is what you should know
Description: A 'bomb cyclone' is forecast to bring heavy snow, high winds and life-threatening flooding to the Pacific Northwest in the next few days. (Image credit: NOAA)

Title: As Nadal plays his last tourney, Federer sends an emotional note from 'your fan, Roger'
Description: You challenged me in ways no one else could,' Roger Federer tells Rafael Nadal, who will retire after this week's Davis Cup tennis tournament. (Image credit: Jack Guez)

Title: Trump's threats of mass deportations lead to hard discussions for families
Description: About 11 million Americans are related to an immigrant without legal status in the U.S. As President-elect Trump ramps up promises of mass deportations, these families are having hard conversations. (Image credit: Yunuen Bonaparte for NPR)

Title: Ukraine attacks Russia with U.S.-made longer-range ATACMS missiles, Moscow says
Description: Ukraine has fired six ATACMS into Russia, the Russian Defense Ministry said. If confirmed, it would mark the first attack using the U.S.-made long-range missiles in 1,000 days of war. (Image credit: John Hamilton)

Title: Ukraine attacks Russia with U.S.-made longer-range ATACAMS missiles, Moscow says
Description: Ukraine has fired six ATACAMS into Russia, the Russian Defense Ministry said. If confirmed, it would mark the first attack using the U.S.-made long-range missiles in 1,000 days of war. (Image credit: John Hamilton)

Title: 1,000 days since Russia invaded Ukraine; Trump's proposed plan for your money
Description: How life in Russia has changed, 1,000 days after its full-scale invasion of Ukraine. And, diving into the consequences of President-elect Donald Trump's proposed tax cuts. (Image credit: Roman Pilipey)

Title: America's first major immigration crackdown and the making and breaking of the West
Description: Chinese immigrants sacrificed to create America's first transcontinental railroad. Its completion may have contributed to a backlash that led to the first major immigration clampdown in U.S. history. (Image credit: Ann Ronan Picture Library/Photo 12)

Title: How to bridge our political divide? A pastor's answer: Do unto others
Description: A Pennsylvania church just blocks from where then-candidate Donald Trump's would-be assassin lived created a sermon series on the Golden Rule to try to bridge political divisions in its congregation. (Image credit: Justin Merriman)

Title: More than a dozen people are killed when Israeli forces moved into central Gaza camp
Description: Nearly 44,000 people have been killed in Gaza by Israeli fire in more than a year of war, according to the ministry of health there. A recent Israeli forces operation took place in central Gaza.

Title: More than a dozen people are killed when Israeli forces moved into Al Bureij camp
Description: Nearly 44,000 people have been killed in Gaza by Israeli fire in more than a year of war, according to the ministry of health there. A recent Israeli forces operation took place in central Gaza.

Title: How to bridge our political divide? A pastor's answer: Do unto others
Description: The pastor of a Pennsylvania church not far from where President-elect Donald Trump was nearly assassinated created a sermon series around the 'Golden Rule' to try to heal a deeply divided community. (Image credit: Justin Merriman)

Title: White House special envoy arrives in Beirut to try to broker ceasefire
Description: Israel bombed parts of central Beirut in what it says is a campaign to destroy the militant group Hezbollah. In return, Hezbollah retaliated with a missile attack on Tel Aviv.

Title: Zama Zamas test South African government's promise to crack down on illegal mining
Description: South African police have been in a stand off outside an abandoned gold mine with hundreds of illegal miners who are holding out underground. The situation is getting desperate.

Title: Bill Clinton delves into his transition from president to citizen in new memoir
Description: The former president talks to Morning Edition about his new book, which details how he's kept busy and tried to make change in the past almost 24 years since leaving the White House (Image credit: Andres Kudacki/AP)

Title: How one Ukrainian soldier and his wife survived 1,000 days of war with Russia
Description: A Ukrainian soldier and his wife describe how the large-scale Russian invasion has changed their lives and their country. (Image credit: Claire Harbage)

Title: How the war with Russia, at the 1,000 day milestone, shaped one soldier and his wife
Description: A Ukrainian soldier and his wife describe how 1,000 days of war have changed their lives and their country.

Title: Trump's election makes the future of what could become a giant lithium mine unclear
Description: In Nevada, federal land managers have approved a new lithium mine that could supply 37,000 new electric cars a year. But a new lawsuit and the reelection of Donald Trump pose challenges.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: It's been 1,000 days since Russia began a full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Dozens of pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong sentenced to prison. What will a second Trump presidency mean for your taxes?

Title: A Biden green energy investment in Nevada that could appeal to Trump
Description: The U.S. has some of the toughest environmental laws in the world and has been content to let other countries mine, and buy many of its critical minerals on the global market. In recent years, there's been a push to get them at home with China and Russia dominating that market. (Image credit: Photo by Kirk Siegler)

Title: Dozens sentenced for up to 10 years in prison in Hong Kong national security case
Description: A Hong Kong court has sentenced 45 pro-democracy activists to up to a decade behind bars after it ruled in a landmark legal case that they had broken a national security law implemented by Beijing. (Image credit: Chan Long Hei)

Title: 42,000 crowd New Zealand's Parliament grounds in support of Māori rights
Description: Protesters oppose a measure that would reshape the county's founding treaty between Indigenous Māori and the British Crown. (Image credit: Mark Tantrum)

Title: Judge strikes down Wyoming abortion laws, including ban on pills to end pregnancy
Description: The decision marks another victory for abortion rights advocates after voters in seven states passed measures in support of access. (Image credit: Charlie Riedel)

Title: Defense pick Peter Hegeth paid accuser to protect his career, his lawyer confirms
Description: The Fox News host reached a settlement to resolve an accusation against him, but a recently released memo brought the issue back into the public eye. (Image credit: Brett Carlsen/Getty Images)

Title: Trump taps Sean Duffy, Fox host and former Congressman, for transportation secretary
Description: President-elect Trump has picked Sean Duffy, a Fox Business host and former Republican congressman from Wisconsin, to head the Department of Transportation. (Image credit: Andy Manis)

Title: Record number of people expected to travel for Thanksgiving
